awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Algorithmic Mechanism Design for Multi-Type Resource Allocation
awd_abstract_narration:
Allocating indivisible items to multiple agents without monetary transfer is a pressing problem in our society. In many situations, items are categorized into multiple types and each agent must get at least one item per type. Such problems are called multi-type resource allocation (MTRA). For example, MTRA arises in allocating courses to students, allocating computational resources to users in cloud computing, allocating medical resources to patients, as well as in multi-type exchange market and centralized welfare programs that involve multiple sub-programs. Unfortunately, most previous research overlook information regarding resource type, and are thus hindered by three barriers: preference bottleneck, computational bottleneck, and threats of agents' strategic behavior. The project aims at establishing theoretical and algorithmic foundations of mechanism design for MTRA with the help of Artificial Intelligence. The newly designed mechanisms will improve the economic efficiency and computational efficiency of resource allocation in multiagent systems, socio-economics systems, and operations research.

In doing so, the researcher will design and evaluate novel graphical languages to address the preference bottleneck; design novel frameworks for discovering new mechanisms, including sequential allocation mechanisms and extensions of the top-trading-cycles mechanism, to address the computational bottleneck; use game theory to analyze and measure agents' strategic behavior; and use high computational complexity to prevent agents' strategic behavior. Outcomes of the research will be integrated into an open-source Online Preference Reporting and Aggregation (OPRA) system, which serves as a platform to bridge theory, practice, and education.

Overview of Goals

Allocating indivisible items to multiple agents without monetary transfer is a pressing problem in our society. In many problems, items are categorized into multiple types and each agent must get at least one item per type. Such problems are called multi-type resource allocation (MTRA). Most previous research overlooked the type information and are hindered by three barriers: preference bottleneck, computational bottleneck, and threats of agents? strategic behavior.  This project aims at addressing these challenges in three directions detailed below.

Intellectual Merit

Direction 1: Novel languages. We developed two compact languages for representing preferences in MTRA: (1) bundle nets [WSG+ AIJ-2023], which generalize previously studied domain restrictions of partial preferences for multiple assignment problems and is incomparable to the domain of acyclic CP-nets, and (2) CMI trees [SAX AAAI-2019], which extends several popular languages studied in previous work and represent preferences over bundles consisting of multiple items of each type.

Direction 2: Novel frameworks. We have proposed three frameworks and provided a comprehensive picture of their fairness and efficiency properties.

1. In [WSG+ AAAI-2020] and its journal version [WSG+ AIJ-2023], we propose multi-type probabilistic serial (MPS) and multi-type random priority (MRP) as extensions of the well-known PS and RP mechanisms to MTRA with partial preferences. Our main message is positive: When agents' preferences are represented by acyclic CP-nets, MPS satisfies sd-efficiency, sd-envy-freeness, ordinal fairness, and upper invariance, while MRP satisfies ex-post-efficiency, sd-strategy-proofness, and upper invariance, recovering the properties of PS and RP. When agents? preferences are lexicographic, we prove that these mechanisms satisfy additional desirable properties [GSW+ JAAMAS-2021].

2. In [SAX AAAI-2019],  we extend the Top-Trading-Cycles (TTC) mechanism to select strict core allocations for MTRA housing markets. In doing so, we introduce housing markets with acceptable bundles as a more general setting where each agent may have arbitrary sets of acceptable bundles. Our extension of TTC is strict core selecting under the weaker restriction on preferences of CMI-trees.

3. In [SGW+ AAMAS-2021], we propose and analyze sequential mechanisms as described in Section 3.2.2. of the proposal, and investigate the relationship between properties of the local mechanisms and the properties of their sequential composition mechanism under lexicographic preferences. We show that under natural conditions, sequential mechanisms satisfy the desirable properties of anonymity, neutrality, non-bossiness, or Pareto-optimality if and only if every local mechanism also satisfies the same property. Our main results are that under O-legal lexicographic preferences, every mechanism satisfying strategyproofness and a combination of these properties must be a sequential composition of local mechanisms that are also strategyproof, and satisfy the same combinations of properties.

 

Direction 3: Agents? strategic behavior. We have primarily focused on analyzing sd-strategy-proofness of newly proposed mechanisms, which has been discussed in Direction 2 above.

Beyond MTRA. This project also contributes to the development of multiple conceptual and technical results for resource allocation problems in general, which can be viewed as MTRA with one category.

1. In [HSVX AAAI-21],  we  prove the existence of EFX and Pareto optimal allocations under lexicographic preferences by providing an algorithmic characterization of these two properties. We also characterize the mechanisms that are, in addition, strategyproof, non-bossy, and neutral. 

2. In [HSV+ AAAI-20], we propose a novel fairness notion based on information withholding, where an agent can withhold (or hide) some of the goods in its bundle and reveal the remaining goods to the other agents. We observe that in practice, envy-freeness can be achieved by withholding only a small number of goods overall. We show that finding allocations that withhold an optimal number of goods is computationally hard even for highly restricted classes of valuations.  

3. In two papers [FSVX IJCAI-2019, AAMAS-2020], we study (approximately) equitable allocation of indivisible good and chores. For goods, our proved that the Leximin algorithm produces an allocation that satisfies equitability up to any good and Pareto optimality. For chores, we proved that there always exists an allocation that is simultaneously equitable up to one chore and Pareto optimal. We also designed pseudopolynomial-time algorithms for both settings.  

4. In [GSX+ JAIR-accepted],  we propose a natural and intuitive efficiency property, favoring-eagerness-for-remaining- items (FERI), which requires that each item is allocated to an agent who ranks it highest among remaining items, thereby implying first-choice maximality. Using FERI as a heuristic, we design mechanisms that satisfy ex-post or ex-ante variants of FERI together with combinations of other desirable properties of efficiency (Pareto-efficiency), fairness (strong equal treatment of equals and sd-weak-envy-freeness), and strategyproofness (sd- weak-strategyproofness). We also explore the limits of FERI mechanisms in providing stronger efficiency, fairness, or strategyproofness guarantees through impossibility results.

 

Broader Impacts: OPRA

This project also improved the open-source Online Preference Reporting and Aggregation (OPRA) system [CQW+ AAAI-21], which continued to provide service to the RPI community and the public.
